conbody.p: Another nifty backend is wai-handler-webkit. This backend combines Warp and QtWebkit to create an executable that a user simply double-clicks. This can be a convenient way to provide an offline version of your application.

One of the very nice conveniences of Yesod for this is that your templates are all compiled into the executable, and thus do not need to be distributed with your application. Static files do, however.
conbody.note: There's actually support for embedding your static files directly in the executable as well, see the yesod-static docs for more details.
conbody.p: A similar approach, without requiring the QtWebkit library, is wai-handler-launch, which launches a Warp server and then opens up the user's default web browser. There's a little trickery involved here: in order to know that the user is still using the site, wai-handler-launch inserts a "ping" Javascript snippet to every HTML page it serves. It wai-handler-launch doesn't receive a ping for two minutes, it shuts down.
